title: Maryland vanquishes Virginia in NCAA men lacrosse semifinal – Daily Press
body_text:
COLLEGE MEN’S LACROSSE
Maryland masters UVA in NCAA semifinal
Seventh-seeded Maryland (11-5) dominated sixth-seeded Virginia 12-6 Saturday in an NCAA semifinal at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia, avenging a 14-10 regular-season loss to the Cavaliers (12-6) and advancing to play top-seeded Notre Dame in Monday’s final.
Eric Spanos had two goals and three assists and Daniel Kelly scored three goals for the Terrapins. McCabe Millon was the only Cavalier with two goals, and Maryland held all-time ACC leading scorer Connor Shellenberger to one goal and one assist. UVA was playing in its 26th NCAA semifinal and has won seven championships.
OBITUARY
Former Spiders star Beckwith dies of heart attack
Richmond and the larger basketball community are mourning the death of former Spiders point guard and current color commentator Greg Beckwith, who died Friday of a heart attack.
Beckwith, a Spiders Hall of Famer, was a key part of a UR team that upset Charles Barkley and Auburn in the 1984 NCAA Tournament. He was a second-team All-CAA and All-State selection in 1985-86, his senior year, and he finished his career as UR’s all-time leader in assists (573) and steals (227). He went on to be a highly respected broadcaster.
COLLEGE FOOTBALL
Former Cincinnati LB transferring to UVA
Virginia gained a commitment from former Cincinnati linebacker Dorian Jones, who changed his mind after originally committing to Texas El Paso as a transfer.
Jones compiled a career-high 56 tackles (2.5 for loss), one interception and one sack in his only season with the Bearcats. He has one season of eligibility left.
LOCAL BASEBALL
Pilots capture first victory
The Peninsula Pilots (1-2) gained their first victory of the Coastal Plain League season, beating the Tri-City Chili Peppers 9-5 Saturday night before 1,103 at Shepherd Stadium in Colonial Heights.
The Pilots trailed 4-0 after Zion Taylor’s grand slam in the first inning but went ahead in the fourth and, after two home defeats, maintained the lead.
Chris Martinez, Luis Delacruz, Cole Stanford and Jevin Relaford each had two of the Pilots’ 12 hits. Cam Pittman scored three runs and Delacruz two.
Winner Gardner Meeks, Darrell Fletcher-Knight and Kenny Leiner each pitched shutout relief for Peninsula, which will go to eastern North Carolina on Sunday to face the Greenville Yard Gnomes.
PRO GOLF
Sellers wins GPro Tour event in Hertford
Grant Sellers of McBee, South Carolina, won the minor-league GPro Tour’s 54-hole Albemarle Championship at Albemarle Plantation in Hertford, North Carolina.
Sellers, a former college star for Division II Francis Marion, took a two-stroke lead into the final round. He finished with a 4-under-par 68 for a 15-under 201, beating Austin Duncan of York, South Carolina, by one stroke and third-place Erik Edwards of Louisville, Kentucky, and the University of Indianapolis by three.
Cameron Moore of Glen Allen, who has played for Virginia Tech since the fall of 2018, tied for 19th at 3 under.
COLLEGE GOLF
UVA gains early lead at NCAAs
Virginia, ranked ninth before the tournament, held first place at 1-over-par 577 following the completion of the morning wave of teams in the second round of the NCAA Championships on Saturday in Carlsbad, California.
Senior George Duangmanee ended his round in second place overall at 2-under 142 after back-to-back 71s. UVA All-American Ben James, the 2023 NCAA Freshman of the Year, also posted a second-round 71 by recording four birdies and three bogeys. Josh Duangmanee, George’s younger brother, was tied with James at even-par 144. They finished the morning wave of the second round in eighth place.
After the first round, UVA shared the lead with Arizona at 2-over 290 at the Omni La Costa Resort’s North Course. North Carolina (291) was third and Georgia Tech (292) fourth. Georgia Tech’s Hiroshi Tai was the individual leader at 67.
Following Sunday’s third round, the field will be cut to 15 teams for the final round of stroke play. The top eight teams from stroke play advance to match play.
COLLEGE TRACK AND FIELD
Kempsville grad qualifies for NCAAs
Howard University senior Noah Langford is headed to the NCAA Division I Outdoor Championships in Eugene, Oregon.
The Kempsville High grad ran a personal-best time of 50.55 seconds to get the final spot in the 400-meter hurdles at the NCAA East Preliminary in Lexington, Kentucky.
His previous best was 50.57, which he ran to win that event in the MEAC Outdoor Championships at Norfolk State earlier this month.
Langford looks to become Howard’s first 400-meter hurdles All-American since 1989.
The Norfolk State men’s team concluded its campaign at the East Preliminary.
Kai Cole opened the evening with a quarterfinal appearance in the 100 meters. The senior completed the race in 10.24 seconds, placing 21st. He will compete in the U.S. Olympic Trials in in Eugene, Oregon.
NSU senior Isaac Haywood made his third consecutive appearance at the regional in the triple jump, placing 20th at 51 feet, 3.5 inches, nearly matching his personal record.
Freshman Premier Wynn was 23rd in the 400 hurdles at 53.75, and NSU’s 4×400 relay placed 21st in 3:07.64.
UVA athletes Shane Cohen (800), Jacob Lemmon (discus), Gary Martin (1,500), Nate Mountain (3,000 steeplechase), Yasin Sado (3,000 steeplechase) and Wes Porter (1,500) joined teammates Will Anthony, John Fay and Janae Profit in qualifying for the NCAAs.
CNU’s Reeders leaps to All-American award
Christopher Newport senior CJ Reeders hauled in All-American accolades in the triple jump in the NCAA Division III outdoor championships in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.
In the triple jump, Reeders placed 13th in the country, which earned him a second-team All-American citation. He posted distances of 14.54 meters (about 47 feet, 8 inches), 14.51 and 14.47. The 14.54 was his second-best distance this season.
A six-time national qualifier, the New Kent High graduate picked up his third All-American accolade.
COLLEGE WOMEN’S TENNIS
CNU players fall in NCAA first round
Christopher Newport junior Raine Weis and senior Tessa Trate dropped singles first-round matches in the NCAA Division III individual championship in St. Louis, and then dropped a first-round doubles match later Saturday.
Weis, the Coast-To-Coast Athletic Conference Player of the Year, lost 6-4, 7-6 (7-3) to the No. 6 seed, Hannah Kassaie of Case Western Reserve. Trate, who made the field as an alternate, lost 6-2, 6-1 to Middlebury’s Sahana Raman.
In doubles, the Captains — ranked ninth in doubles, an all-time CNU women’s high — lost 6-3, 6-3 to fourth-seeded Matia Cristiani and Olivia Soffer of Babson, last year’s NCAA runners-up.
